title: 110_hr1395
content: The Act may be cited as the "Government Credit Card Abuse Prevention Act of 2007". Management of purchase cards is addressed in the Act. The "Government Credit Card Abuse Prevention Act of 2007" requires executive agencies to establish safeguards and controls for purchase cards, including record-keeping, assigning approving officials, and reconciling charges. The "Government Credit Card Abuse Prevention Act of 2007" mandates executive agencies to establish controls for purchase cards, including reconciling charges with receipts and forwarding for timely payment. Disputed charges are resolved as per the Governmentwide purchase card contract, and payments are made promptly to avoid interest penalties. Rebates and refunds are received based on prompt payment. (6) Rebates and refunds for prompt payment on purchase card accounts are accurately monitored and recorded as receipts to the paying agency. (7) Records of each purchase card transaction are retained in accordance with Government policies. (8) Periodic reviews are conducted to assess the necessity of purchase cards for each cardholder. (9) Training is provided to cardholders and officials overseeing purchase card use. (10) Specific policies are in place regarding the issuance of purchase cards by different organizations within the executive agency. The executive agency issues purchase cards to eligible employees and organizations with specific credit limits. Policies are in place to minimize financial risk and ensure cardholder integrity. Technologies are used to prevent fraudulent purchases, including monitoring merchant codes and utilizing machine learning. Purchase cards are invalidated for employees who cease employment. The executive agency issues purchase cards to eligible employees with credit limits and safeguards in place to prevent fraudulent purchases. Upon termination or transfer of an employee, the agency takes steps to recover any improper purchases, including salary offsets. Regulations are in place for managing purchase cards and penalties for violations. The executive agency issues purchase cards to eligible employees with credit limits and safeguards in place to prevent fraudulent purchases. Regulations provide for adverse personnel actions or punishment for violations, negligence, misuse, abuse, or fraud with purchase cards, including referral to the United States Attorney for suspected fraud and dismissal for egregious abuse. The Inspector General of each agency conducts periodic risk assessments of the purchase card program and internal controls. The purchase card program includes internal controls to prevent improper activity. Periodic audits of cardholders are conducted to identify fraudulent and improper card usage, patterns of improper transactions, and categories of purchases that should not be made with purchase cards. Results of audits are reported to the agency head. The purchase card program conducts periodic audits of cardholders to prevent improper activity and identify fraudulent transactions. Results of audits are reported to the agency head, the Director of the Office of Management and Budget, and the Comptroller General. The requirements under this section do not apply to the Department of Defense, except for specific amendments to Section 2784(b) of title 10, United States Code. The Code is amended to require risk assessments of the agency purchase card program, analyze weaknesses, and determine the scope of audits. The Department of Defense must use technologies to prevent fraudulent purchases. The Department of Defense uses pattern recognition technologies to review transaction risks. The Secretary of Defense invalidates purchase cards of employees who leave or transfer within the department. SEC. 3. MANAGEMENT OF TRAVEL CARDS. Management of Travel Charge Cards: The Travel and Transportation Reform Act of 1998 amends Section 2 by adding new subsection (h) requiring executive agencies to establish safeguards and controls over travel charge cards. This includes maintaining records of cardholders and ensuring proper recording of rebates and refunds for prompt payments. The Travel and Transportation Reform Act of 1998 requires executive agencies to establish safeguards and controls over travel charge cards. This includes proper recording of receipts, periodic reviews of cardholder needs, training for cardholders and officials, and specific policies on card issuance and credit limits. The Travel and Transportation Reform Act of 1998 mandates executive agencies to establish policies for issuing travel charge cards to eligible individuals. These policies aim to minimize financial risks to the Federal Government and ensure cardholder integrity. Agencies must negotiate with card providers to assess individuals' creditworthiness before issuing cards, denying cards to those found not creditworthy. The Travel and Transportation Reform Act of 1998 requires executive agencies to establish policies for issuing travel charge cards to eligible individuals. Agencies must assess individuals' creditworthiness based on a minimum credit score determined through statistical analysis. This evaluation includes reviewing consumer reports from consumer reporting agencies. The executive agencies use technology to prevent fraudulent purchases and ensure immediate invalidation of travel charge cards for employees who leave the agency. The termination of employee employment in executive agencies may result in penalties for violations related to travel charge card misuse, abuse, or fraud, including removal in appropriate cases. Regulations and safeguards are implemented to prevent such actions, with penalties prescribed by the Administrator of General Services. The Inspector General of each agency conducts assessments to ensure compliance. The Inspector General of each executive agency conducts risk assessments and periodic audits of travel cardholders to identify fraudulent and improper uses of travel cards. Reports on audit results are submitted to the agency head and the Director of the Office. The Inspector General of each executive agency conducts risk assessments and audits of travel cardholders to identify fraudulent and improper card uses. Reports on audit results are submitted to the agency head, the Director of the Office of Management and Budget, and the Comptroller General for implementation of recommendations. Definitions for "executive agency" and "travel charge card" are provided in this subsection. SEC. 4. MANAGEMENT OF CENTRALLY BILLED ACCOUNTS. The head of an executive agency with employees using centrally billed accounts must establish safeguards to prevent duplicate reimbursements and request refunds for unauthorized purchases or unused tickets. Regulations must be promulgated within 180 days of the Act's enactment to implement requirements for purchase card and travel card programs, reflecting best practices.
